At 75 years old, McGuigan's sub-52 minute performance established the benchmark for the M75 category and demonstrated that competitive racing continues well into masters athletics.

brian-mcbride.headline: M70 Age Record Holder and Three-Time M70 Winner
notable_achievements: M70 age record holder at Lough 5 (37:19, 2022)
Donegal Senior XC Championships M70 winner (23:28, 2025)
brian-mcbride.above_the_fold: Brian McBride set the M70 age record at the 2022 Lough 5 with 37:19, launching a three-year dominance of the category with victories in 2022, 2024, and 2025. The Letterkenny AC masters athlete has excelled across all disciplines: silver at the 2025 National Masters Indoor 1500m Championships (6:41.33), victory at the Donegal Senior Cross Country Championships M70 (23:28), and 13:48 at the Armagh International 3km. His range from 1500m track through cross country to 5-mile roads demonstrates exceptional versatility. At over 70 years old, McBride represents the competitive masters athlete who continues to set records, win championships, and inspire through sustained excellence across every racing surface.

pat-odriscoll.headline: M75 Age Record Holder and Five-Time Competitor
notable_achievements: M75 age record holder at Lough 5 (58:40, 2024)
pat-odriscoll.above_the_fold: Pat O'Driscoll set the M75 age record at the 2024 Lough 5 with 58:40, returning eight years after his debut. The North Down AC athlete won the M70 title in 2017 (48:36) before claiming M75 gold in 2024. His five appearances across nine years demonstrate remarkable longevity and sustained competitive fitness into his late seventies. O'Driscoll's back-to-back age group titles showcase consistent racing across multiple masters categories, representing those athletes who compete well into their eighth decade with commitment and consistency.

paul-mccafferty.headline: M45 Age Record Holder and Back-to-Back M45 Winner
notable_achievements: M45 age record holder at Lough 5 (28:07, 2015)
Round the Bridges 10 Mile M40 winner (58:19, 2012)
paul-mccafferty.above_the_fold: Paul McCafferty set the M45 age record at the 2015 Lough 5 with 28:07, then defended his title in 2016 (28:19). The City of Derry athlete's road racing credentials extend beyond Lough 5: winner of the Finn Valley 5K and M40 champion at the Round the Bridges 10 Mile (58:19). His back-to-back M45 titles demonstrate sustained masters excellence, with both performances ranking among the fastest age-group times ever recorded. McCafferty represents the masters athlete who maintains championship form across multiple seasons.

peter-ohara.headline: M65 Age Record Holder and Back-to-Back M65 Winner
notable_achievements: M65 age record holder at Lough 5 (34:24, 2023)
peter-ohara.above_the_fold: Peter O'Hara set the M65 age record at the 2023 Lough 5 with 34:24, improving 89 seconds from his 2022 M65 title-winning debut (35:53). The Flying Machine athlete's back-to-back M65 championships showcase remarkable year-on-year improvement in his mid-sixties. O'Hara represents those masters athletes who continue to progress even as they age, demonstrating that dedicated training can yield significant improvements regardless of decade.

roisin-doyle.headline: F70 Age Record Holder
notable_achievements: F70 age record holder at Lough 5 (54:50, 2023)
roisin-doyle.above_the_fold: Roisin Doyle set the F70 age record at the 2023 Lough 5 with 54:50, claiming the F70 title in her debut appearance. The Pace Running Club athlete returned in 2024 and 2025, demonstrating continued competitive spirit across three consecutive years. Doyle represents female masters athletes who continue racing into their seventies, inspiring others with her sustained commitment to the sport.

matthew-mclaughlin.headline: 2021 M40 Champion
notable_achievements: 2021 M40 champion at Lough 5 (27:25) - #39 fastest male all-time
matthew-mclaughlin.above_the_fold: Matthew McLaughlin claimed the 2021 M40 title with 27:25, securing #39 on the all-time male list for Foyle Valley AC.

james-speight.headline: 2025 Silver Medalist and #19 on the All-Time List
james-speight.above_the_fold: James Speight returned to the Lough 5 after a 13-year absence to claim silver at the 2025 edition with 26:04 — a performance that secured #19 on the all-time male list and demonstrated remarkable longevity. The Finn Valley/Dromore AC athlete first appeared in 2012, finishing 4th overall with 26:59, fresh off a breakthrough year that saw him run 16:03 for 5K and 33:05 for 10K. His 2025 comeback improved on that debut time by 55 seconds, showcasing sustained fitness across more than a decade. Speight's athletic pedigree runs deep: a 4:03 1500m runner in 2011, Irish Schools' steeplechase champion, and international cross country competitor who represented Ireland at the Home Countries International and World Mountain Running Trophy. His ability to return at an elite level after such a long gap speaks to consistent training and competitive spirit. His two appearances bookend over a decade of racing, making his silver medal one of the most impressive comeback performances in recent Lough 5 history.

james-monaghan.headline: 2024 M40 Silver Medalist
notable_achievements: 2024 M40 silver medalist at Lough 5 (27:29) - #44 fastest male all-time
james-monaghan.above_the_fold: James Monaghan claimed M40 silver at the 2024 Lough 5 with 27:29 and 6th overall — securing #44 on the all-time male list in his debut for St Peter's AC.

monica-mcgranaghan.headline: F40 Bronze Medalist
notable_achievements: 2019 F40 bronze medalist at Lough 5 (32:46) - #49 fastest female all-time
monica-mcgranaghan.above_the_fold: Monica McGranaghan claimed F40 bronze at the 2019 Lough 5 with 32:46, finishing 8th female and securing #49 on the all-time female list for Letterkenny AC.

enda-mckaigue.headline: 2021 M35 Silver Medalist
notable_achievements: 2021 M35 silver medalist at Lough 5 (27:52) - #47 fastest male all-time
enda-mckaigue.above_the_fold: Enda McKaigue claimed M35 silver at the 2021 Lough 5 with 27:52, securing #47 on the all-time male list. The Acorns AC/Strive Racing Club athlete's two appearances included 7th overall in 2019 (27:41).

joan-maguire.headline: 2024 F40 Champion
notable_achievements: 2024 F40 champion at Lough 5 (33:00) - #45 fastest female all-time
joan-maguire.above_the_fold: Joan Maguire claimed the 2024 F40 title with 33:00 and 8th female — securing #45 on the all-time female list in her debut for Dromore Runners.

aidan-ohagan-strive.headline: 2019 M40 Champion and 2021 Silver Medalist
notable_achievements: 2021 M40 silver medalist (27:43) - #48 fastest male all-time
Strive Racing Club, previously Acorns AC
aidan-ohagan-strive.above_the_fold: Aidan O'Hagan's two Lough 5 appearances showcase consistent excellence in the M40 category. The Acorns AC athlete won M40 gold in 2019 with 28:16 and 10th overall, then returned in 2021 representing Strive Racing Club to claim silver with an improved time of 27:43 and 11th overall — securing #48 on the all-time male list.

elaine-mcguckin.headline: 2023 F40 Champion
elaine-mcguckin.above_the_fold: Elaine McGuckin claimed the 2023 F40 title with 33:03 and 7th female in her debut for Keep 'er lit.

ivan-toner.headline: 2013 M35 Silver Medalist
notable_achievements: 2013 M35 silver medalist at Lough 5 (27:44) - #49 fastest male all-time
ivan-toner.above_the_fold: Ivan Toner claimed M35 silver at the 2013 Lough 5 with 27:44 and 4th overall — securing #49 on the all-time male list for Letterkenny AC.

kristopher-muldoon.headline: 2010 Bronze Medalist
kristopher-muldoon.above_the_fold: Kristopher Muldoon claimed overall bronze at the 2010 Lough 5 with 28:34, then returned in 2012 with his best time of 27:48 — securing #50 on the all-time male list for Armagh AC.

barbara-murray.headline: F45 Silver Medalist
notable_achievements: 2021 F45 silver medalist at Lough 5 (33:12) - #49 fastest female all-time
barbara-murray.above_the_fold: Barbara Murray claimed F45 silver at the 2021 Lough 5 with 33:12 — securing #49 on the all-time female list.

bridget-murphy.headline: F35 Silver Medalist
notable_achievements: Dungannon's Little running club / Keep 'er lit
bridget-murphy.above_the_fold: Bridget Murphy claimed F35 silver at the 2023 Lough 5 with 34:01. Her 2021 debut produced 33:31 — securing #50 on the all-time female list for Dungannon's Little running club.
